importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The US began a series of strikes on drug-smuggling vessels in the Caribbean starting in September, marking the beginning of a major counter-narcotics military campaign.
The latest development involving the release of the Ecuadorean survivor occurs on this date, highlighting the ongoing international scrutiny and diplomatic tension surrounding the US operations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from September to October 2025 is central to the article, during which the US conducted at least seven strikes, resulting in multiple deaths and the capture of survivors, raising legal and diplomatic concerns.

keyTakeAways: The US military conducted multiple strikes in the Caribbean targeting vessels alleged to be smuggling drugs, with at least 32 people killed in seven attacks since September.
Two survivors—Andrés Fernando Tufiño (Ecuadorean) and Jeison Obando Pérez (Colombian)—were captured after a strike on a semi-submersible vessel, which the US claimed was a drug-carrying submarine.

The Ecuadorean Attorney General's office stated there was no evidence of a crime committed by Tufiño, leading to his release; the Colombian survivor has a traumatic brain injury and is being treated in Bogotá.
The US claims the vessel was transporting fentanyl and other narcotics, but experts argue that fentanyl primarily enters the US from Mexico, not the southern Caribbean.

The US deployment includes around 10,000 troops and numerous military assets, targeting vessels departing Venezuela, with accusations against Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro of leading a drug trafficking group.
Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro denies drug trafficking allegations and claims the operations are aimed at removing him from power.

Colombian President Gustavo Petro accused the US of violating Colombian territorial waters in a September strike, calling it 'murder,' and Trump responded by calling Petro an 'illegal drug leader' and threatening to cut aid and impose tariffs.
Trinidad and Tobago expressed support for US intervention, citing the goal of reducing transnational crime and achieving regional peace.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Ecuador has released Andrés Fernando Tufiño, a survivor of a US military strike on a semi-submersible vessel in the Caribbean, due to the absence of any legal charge of criminal activity in Ecuadorean territory. The US claims the vessel was a drug-carrying submarine transporting fentanyl, and that it was targeting 'narco-terrorists,' including members of the Cartel of the Suns linked to Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro. However, experts question the legality and accuracy of these claims, noting that fentanyl primarily enters the US from Mexico, not the southern Caribbean. The US has carried out at least seven strikes since September 2025, killing at least 32 people and capturing two survivors—Tufiño and Jeison Obando Pérez. The Colombian survivor suffers a traumatic brain injury and is receiving treatment in Bogotá, while the US and Colombia have exchanged sharp diplomatic words, with Petro accusing the US of violating territorial waters and Trump retaliating with threats of aid cuts and tariffs. Meanwhile, Trinidad and Tobago supports the US military intervention, emphasizing regional peace and anti-trafficking goals.
title: Ecuador releases survivor of US strike on 'drug sub' in Caribbean
